description: From Middle English overstonden, from Old English oferstandan (“to stand over”), equivalent to over- +‎ stand. Cognate with Dutch overstaan (“to stand over”), German überstehen (“to stand through, survive”).

entries.meaning: (lutherie) The measurement between the top plate and the fingerboard where the neck meets the body of the instrument.

verbs.description: overstand (third-person singular simple present overstands, present participle overstanding, simple past and past participle overstood)

entries.meaning: (rare) To stand or insist too much or too long; overstay.
examples: But they that overstand the day of grace, shall not obtain to cool their tongues so much of this water as will hang on the tip of one's finger.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stand too strictly on the demands or conditions of.
(yachting, boat racing): To sail to the mark at a wider angle than is the normal upwind angle, to go beyond the layline
(forestry, of a coppice): To be neglected and left uncut for too long.

description: Blend of over +‎ understand, coined in Rastafarianism before 1965.

verbs.description: overstand (third-person singular simple present overstands, present participle overstanding, simple past and past participle overstood)

entries.meaning: (Rastafarianism, US black subculture): To have complete or intuitive comprehension of; to understand fully.
